wikipedia_page.main: Clive Emsley (4 August 1944 – 5 October 2020) was a British historian and criminologist.  He was a research director and lecturer at the Open University.

Marwick had a flamboyant and outgoing personality. A. W. Purdue described him as "alternatively, wonderful, outrageous and dangerous to know. Kind and supportive to colleagues, he was an heroic drinker but not always fun after the first few drinks." Jonathan Meades called him "the very picture of baba-cool, with his daringly arty shirt, negligently loose foulard and his beardy grin for which the only word is that late Sixties shocker 'mellow'". His colleague Clive Emsley, however, recalled a more complex character:

response: Police History has become an area of study in itself with organisations such as the Police History Society existing since 1985 to further develop this field of knowledge. It is recognised as specialist area of academia with notable experts including Clive Emsley, Dr Chris Williams, Martin Stallion and Richard Cowley leading in this field.
